narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A great introduction to foundational Black Feminist texts, thoughts and concepts.

I was able to read from a breadth of Black Feminist texts, learning about the contextual lived histories of the Black feminist scholars and activists whose works we were reading. Through the course, we also had the incredible opportunity to speak with some of the writers whose works we read, learning from them firsthand.
I learned about the history of Black feminist thought, including themes of intersectionality, diaspora, anti-violence movements, state violence

I had the opportunity to read and discuss important texts by Black feminist scholars like Angela Davis, Gail Lewis, and Christina Sharpe. I think I gained an understanding of some (but certainly not all) key insights and interventions of Black feminism, including the importance of standpoint epistemology, the racist and sexist fiction of the Black matriarch discourse, and Sharpe's concept of "wake work."
abolitionist frameworks; intersections of citizenship, race, gender, and class; body politics; politics of sexual violence; reading and writing techniques
SO MUCH, foundational knowledge in black feminist theory, but also I gained a new lens to look at the world, by far an amazing course, what I learned is so valuable

I learned so much about the history of Black Feminist Theory, its connections to abolition, care, and intersectionality, as well as the critical implications of its scholars in a variety of social issues.
Black Fem theory and the different format/topics they reach!
You read many amazing Black feminist authors and get the chance to discuss them both in seminar and in section. Prof. Ferguson is truly amazing and his mini lectures were always very interesting.

This course gave me a thorough education on Black Feminist Theory and the history of the movements started by Black feminists, particularly queer Black women. Because of the amount of reading we did each week I learned how to effectively analyze political writings.
We had wonderful TAs, a wonderful professor, and an amazing reading list with authors such as Angela Davis, Gail Lewis, Toni Morrison, etc.
Read and discussed Black Feminist texts from mostly the US but also the Caribbean and England.
I learned a lot about Black feminisms, about theory, about radicalism. One of the best classes I have taken at Yale.

This class offers a very comprehensive look at Black Feminist Theory. I learned a lot about the ideas and major theorists within the field and I developed better reading and analytical skills. The course relates eagily related concepts with the real world, and that application helps ground material while also making it more approachable and accessible.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I appreciated the comfortable and chill learning environment that was cultivated by prof. r and the TAs and freedom and flexibility we enjoyed with the assignments. Given the amazing readings and concepts we engaged with, it was clear that the instructor prioritized genuine knowledge acquisition and reflection compared to those that prioritize grades and unrealistic forms of evolution. Getting to hear from Beth RIchie and Gail Lewis when they came to our class was also phenomenal. Loved the freedom we had in crafting our final projects as well!

Professor Ferguson's mini-lectures at the beginnings of each class, the TFs and their wonderfully led small group discussions and contributions, and the readings were definitely great strengths of the class. Our class, while big, was pretty quiet, so sometimes class discussions were a little quiet.
strengths: content, syllabus, Prof. Ferguson; weaknesses: none
Professor Ferguson was a great lecturer, but our class discussions were quite lacking. I think there were too many people on zoom for people to feel safe actually speaking up.

Professor Ferguson is wonderful and has a nice way of expanding on students' comments and bringing out new ideas. The TAs were all very engaged and engaging. For the short writing assignments, I would have preferred to make more extended connections between the texts and cultural/political phenomena, instead of doing vague creative thinking exercises.

Strengths: The readings are beautiful and stretch your mind and heart to places of deeper consideration.  All seminars had a lecture component to it which helped in recapping our readings and catching folks up if they weren't able to complete readings/if the content was difficult to understand. 

Weaknesses: being online is rough. Also, more conversational prompts could've helped small group discussion. We did a group activity the last week, however, that was nice.

All around great professor/TAs. Great discussion and modes of thinking. The class itself just refused to engage, except for a few which to me spoke to the broader Yale culture expectation to only speak if it will be profound or correct. This class does not call for that, which is a plus. The class would've been so much better if people felt comfortable being wrong or not performing

NO WEAKNESSES
an amazing course
actually amazing
Strength: amazing readings, wonderful professors and tfs, really thoughtful discussions. Weaknesses: none.

I loved the way the class practiced what it thought, in leaving room for creativity and nonacademic language. I also really enjoyed hearing from theorists themselves! In terms of weaknesses, I think maybe including more texts like Assata, that are less academicy and get down to communicating the lives of Black women. I also think it may have been helpful to have gotten more distinct due dates for assignments in the beginning of the semester, sometimes it got overwhelming when several were piled on students out of the blue.
No weaknesses, a truly spectacular class.

I loved the discussion sections. They were so useful, especially because after our main class I was often still confused on some parts of the readings. Professor Ferguson was immensely helpful in making the course accessible and enjoyable for us all. We had guest speakers, which was always amazing because we got to learn from original Black feminists. I think that the breakout rooms could have been better during the main class, but that's mainly because it was easy to not involve yourself in them.
Professor Ferguson and the TAs were extremely caring and they did a very good job of facilitating conversations.
Really no weaknesses! It was a great class and I learned so much from Professor Ferguson and the other students.
This class is absolutely incredible. Everything is a strength.
No weaknesses it was awesome.

The course is organized well and the content is interesting. Professor Ferguson and all the TFs are fantastic, perhaps in the future the course could offer more opportunities for students to create a classroom community so therefore conversation would flow more easily (maybe through short social activities throughout the semester or opportunites for breakout rooms for students to talk about material w/o TF oversight).

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The understanding and compassionate nature of the professor and TAs helped making the course manageable and even enjoyable during the pandemic. In order to decrease zoom fatigue, it may help to eliminate separate section times entirely.
The ability, as facilitated by virtual discussion, to have amazing speakers attend our class was a great privilege and benefit.
Prof. Ferguson was caring and flexible with due dates
Discussions were a bit rocky over Zoom (lots of extended silences). I thought it was helpful when Professor Ferguson started the class with mini lectures to contextualize and summarize the readings.

Success: people zooming in for guest lectures; cam off for times when being as present was difficult but learning was still accessible

Improved: general struggle of being online that can't really be fixed unless we're in person
all of the elements during COVID-19 succeeded, the professor and tfs were all accessible and discussion was valued

I think the discussion sections were really helpful, and the instructors were all super accommodating. those both helped everyone stay on top of the material, even when things were more chaotic around us.

Very very understanding (especially on the end of TFs) though in practice, being more clear on due dates would have been more helpful. I also liked using the hats and not fearing silence for Zoom engagement.
At time, class discussion could be dead, but also it was a pandemic and everyone was zooming in with varying situations so this was very understandable.
Professor Ferguson did a great job of using breakout rooms to continue discussions. It was a really wonderful way of using technology to enhance the already great class.
The way the class was conducted was a success! In addition, Professor Ferguson and the TFs were mindful of ability and I really appreciated that.
We got a ton of understanding and flexibility and it was so much appreciated.

The course could be improved by providing more space for discussion. The style of teaching was effective, but some weeks were more lecture than seminar and I think that led to students not feeling as comfortable to share and discuss in a seminar style. The class might have been too big for that to be able to happen effectively this year, but it is a consideration moving forward.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely! Prof. r is amazing and the material in the course syllabus is amazing. Black feminist theory is amazing.

I would definitely recommend this course to any student interested in learning more about the history of Black feminist thought, learning from Professor Ferguson, who is a great professor, and getting to read wonderful entries into Black feminist theory.
YES. Everyone should be required to take a course on Black feminist theory, especially if Prof. Ferguson is teaching it
YES!! especially if post-pandemic
Yes, you'll read wonderful texts by radical thinkers like Angela Davis and Assata Shakur.
Yes, absolutely yes. There are few places in schools or the world in general that will prioritize Black feminist theory, experience, and narrative.
Absolutely. The professor and TAs were wonderful and the subject matter is so integral to any other niche of the humanities (and the world) that you ever want to explore.
YES, in a heart beat, if you can take any class with professor Ferguson, take it!! 100/10

YES!!!! Professor Ferguson is a wonderful person, teacher, and scholar. He made everyone feel welcome, and he guided us through thoughtful interpretations of BFT. You will learn so much, and you will love everything you read.
Yes! I think it's a super chill class that you get a lot out of. I also think that reading Assata in the middle of a semester was incredible and transformative.

I would 100% recommend this course. Prof. Ferguson is completely geared towards supporting student learning. His use of the "hats" is really fun and useful. A highly necessary course. The guest speakers were also phenomenal.

Yes. I loved this course and I think all students should be required to learn about Black Feminist Theory and those who have informed revolutionary politics like Assata Shakur and Angela Davis. The professor is amazing, and so are all of the TFs.
Yes! Take any course taught my Professor Ferguson! I can't sing his praises enough!
Yes, definitely! I sincerely hope Yale continues to offer more courses in Black Feminist Theory.
Absolutely. You must take this class.
YES. The material was so engaging and the structure is well organized. The Professor and TFs were super knowledgeable and understandingthis course was a pleasure.
Yes! This class is interesting, relevant, and Professor Ferguson is fantastic!
